description.narrative: Mainstreaming coastal and marine biodiversity conservation into production sectors in the Sindhudurg Coast, Maharashtra.

1. Prepare Landscape-level zoning and Management Plan 2. Establish a formal stakeholder consultation committee for cross-sectoral engagement and action 3. Undertake two Research studies a. Prepare a plan for sustainable fisheries management based on an ecosystem approach b. Prepare of a plan for sustainable tourism inter alia mainstreaming biodiversity consideration initiated.
4. Undertake revision of Malvan Marine Sanctuary Management Plan 5. Number of Workshops on Landscape conserving coastal and Marine Diversity organized 6. Number of exposure visits in and outside India organized 7. Number of National and International avenues utilized to share project achievements

comment.narrative: 1. 0 2. 0 3. a. Limited capacity for Ecosystem Approach to Fisheries (EAF) and Biodiversity Mainstreaming 3. b. Baseline - very poorly planned tourism and unregulated in the nature 4. 0 5. 0 6. 0 7.0

1. complete Landscape level planning of Sindhudurg Coastal and Marine Eco-system (SCME) 2. Establish Mangrove foundation 3. Prepare Tourism Management plan of SCME 4. Adopt the use of square mesh net at cod-end by trawlers in Sindhudurg 5. Empower the fisheries officials of the coastal districts of Maharashtra to enforce the provisions of WLPA, 1972, pertaining coastal and marine biodiversity conservation 6. Implement the Solid waste management programme in Vengurla taluka 7. Demonstrate and upscale the Sustainable mariculture practices 8. Acquire Land for crab hatchery 9. Impact assessment of the SCME 10. Adopt System of Rice Intensification (SRI) at the district level

1. Landscape level planning of SCME is nearing completion 2. Mangrove foundation has been established, work plan for 2016-17 with budget of Rs.10 Cr. approved, includes mangrove restoration, marine biodiversity conservation, marine sanctuary and upscaling Square mesh net and mariculture 3. Tourism Management plan of SCME has been prepared. 4. Use of square mesh net at cod-end by trawlers has been adopted in Sindhudurg and the same is being adopted by trawlers in other districts. 5. The fisheries officials of the coastal districts of Maharashtra have been empowered to enforce the provisions of WLPA, 1972, pertaining coastal and marine biodiversity conservation 6. Solid waste management programme in Vengurla taluka has been carried out through our support by the municipal corporation which has in turn become plastic free and open defecation free and has received national level awards ‘Basundhra’ for urban local bodies, ‘Cleanest City and Open Defecation free City’ under ‘Swachya Bharat Abhiyan’. Joint patrolling has been implemented and it resulted in reducing incidences of incursion of MFVs from outside the district and other states in the coastal waters of Sindhudurg. It has also reduced conflict between MFVs and traditional fishing boats in coastal waters reserved for traditional fishing. 7. Sustainable mariculture practices viz. crab farming, oyster culture, muscle culture and IMTA have been successfully demonstrated to 299 beneficiaries and the activities are being considered for upscaling by the fisheries department across all the coastal districts of Maharashtra under its ‘Blue Revolution’ scheme. 8. Land for crab hatchery has been acquired and first draft of Detailed Project Report has been received. 9. Gender mainstreaming and socio-economic impact assessment of the SCME has been taken up. 10. System of Rice Intensification (SRI) has been adopted by the district administration in its Kharif and Rabi paddy production programme and 1000 acres will be covered d

1. Incorporating Landscape level plan and vulnerability mapping into development programmes of the Sindhudurg Coastal and Marine Eco-system (SCME). 2. Mangrove Foundation will initiate co-financing various conservation programs relating cetaceans, turtles, corals and marine eco-sensitive zones. 50 % of the Angria Bank (Phase II) project cost will be supported by the Foundation 3. Management plan for Malvan Marine Sanctuary (MMS) will be prepared 4. 3 Ecotourism and 5 nature trail programmes will be initiated. 5. Coral restoration through Artificial Reefs and coral transplantation will be carried out 6. 2nd phase of Angria Bank expedition will be carried out and permanent monitoring stations will be marked. 7. Scaling up of all the mariculture programmes across coastal Maharashtra under Blue Revolution Scheme will be carried out. 8. System of Rice Intensification (SRI) will be scaled up across all the potential districts in Maharashtra. 9. Mangrove Foundation to initiate scaling up of livelihood activities in other coastal districts as part of exit strategy.

Incorporated landscape level plan and coastal vulnerability mapping into SCME management plan. Mangrove Foundation co-financed various conservation programs relating cetaceans, turtles, corals, marine eco-sensitive zones. Prepared management plan for Malvan Marine Sanctuary. Established 3 ecotourism and 5 nature trails, coral restoration and Angria Bank Expedition (Phase II). Established Multi-Species hatchery and scaled up mariculture activities under ‘Blue Revolution’ scheme, and SRI paddy cultivation. As an exit strategy for the project, Mangrove Foundation has begun initiating scaling up of livelihood activities in other coastal districts

description.narrative: To mainstream biodiversity conservation considerations into those production sectors that impact coastal and marine ecosystems of the SCME
Extent of coral reefs in the project area

comment.narrative: 360 sqkm and this will be verified in first 6 months of the project
The extent of coral cover remains at least stable or increasing

Following achievements made in respect of Coral conservation
1 Studies on Coral and Associated species of Sindhudurg by the Zoological Survey of India i Species recorded Corals14 species Molluscs16 species Echinoderms 3 species Crustaceans 12 sp Polychaetes 3 sp Fishes 38 sp Seaweeds 7 sp
ii Permanent plots marked
iii New genus of Corals viz Pavona bipartita and Goniopora minor have been identified
2 Exploration of Angria Bank approx 100 species have been identified during the first expedition Based on the findings of the study it has been proposed to declare a Marine Reserve in the area covering a submerged plateau of 700 Sq Km
3 Setting up of Artificial Reef and Coral transplantation in an area of 025 Sq km area along Sindhudurg coast has been initiated

description.narrative: Landscape level zoning plan LP that zones resource use by taking into account conservation needs of the SCME

comment.narrative: 1 Landscape Plan that prepared and integrated with the District level planning process

EOIs have been floated thrice and no suitable agencies could be shortlisted This is because landscape level plans for coastal and marine biodiversity conservation is a relatively new concept in India and there is limited or no precedent of such initiatives New strategies for identifying agencies are being worked out through a consultative process This matter has been taken up to NPSC and SPSC
Cross Sectoral Stakeholder Consultation Committee CSSCC formation has already taken place
MFRA does not adequately incorporate the integration of the conservation of coastal and marine biodiversity
Amendments to MFRA incorporating provisions for the conservation of coastal and marine biodiversity approved or under consideration by State Department of Agriculture Fisheries

The Commissioner of Fisheries Government of Maharashtra has made it mandatory to use square mesh at cod end of Trawl nets
Restriction of vessel size CPUE is under consideration by Government of Maharashtra
In order to deal with issues of interstate nature a national fisheries Consultation has been planned to review the marine fisheries regulations of the coastal states in this regard during 2015 Due to Lok Sabha State Assembly elections during 2014 this workshop could not be conducted as planned

description.narrative: Zoning of MMS in line with LP

comment.narrative: Current MMS boundaries do not capture key biodiversity rich areas and there is conflict with local fishermen on resource use issues
MMS boundaries and zoning are rationalized to accord protection to biodiversity rich areas and to guarantee occupational interests and innocent passage of local fishers

Several studies for profiling the key biodiversity elements of the SCME covering Corals Associated flora fauna Cetaceans Avifauna Mangroves Turtles etc have been initiated The outcome of these studies wills assist in rationalizing the boundaries and Zoning of MMS 2 Several meetings have been conducted for discussion with the local communities After setting up of the interpretation centre and the Foundation the issues relating to the rationalizing of MMS will be taken up

Improving energy efficiency in commercial buildings through Implementation and operationalization of Energy Conservation Building Code (ECBC)
PMU Functional, Inception proceedings completed, Workshop proceedings completed

comment.narrative: 1. Establish 5 ECBC cells 2. Train 30 Master trainers 3. Conduct 30 training programmes for different target groups 4. Identify at least 5 buildings to comply to Energy Conservation Building Codes

ECBC notified in 10 states. 10 more states have made amendments, and two cities (Cuttack and Dharamshala) initiated actions. Developed energy performance index (EPI) for commercial buildings. Average EPI is 193 kWh per m2 per year. ECBC compliant construction is complete in few buildings namely SMS Hospital Jaipur, UPERC building in Lucknow, KK Guest House in Bangalore (expected EPIs are less than 100). ECBC compliance included in procurement schedule of Public Works Department, Government of Karnataka. Trained 3,300 building sector on ECBC implementation through 82 training programmes.
1. Establish 10 ECBC cells 2. Create awareness and train 300 people on ECBC implementation 3. Design at least 24 buildings with ECBC compliance 4. Pilot Energy Monitoring Information Systems (EMIS)

Provided technical assistance to implement (complete in some/ ECBC compliant design and issue tender in some) ECBC compliant buildings in about 35 buildings cumulating to 1.47 million m2. Piloted Energy Management Information System to establish Energy Performance dashboard at BEE [UNDP Russia model].Prepared a roadmap for implementing energy efficiency particularly ECBC (to scale up from present less than 1% building stock that is energy efficient).

title.narrative: Improving Energy Efficiency in Indian Railways System

description.narrative: Improving Energy Efficiency in Indian Railways(IR) system by wide adoption of energy efficiency technologies and measures in the IR system

title.narrative: Terminal Evaluation - Improving Energy Effeciency in Indian Railways
Implementation of Building Management Intelligent System and Lighting System Upgrade in Rail Bhawan, New Delhi
Implementation of Building Management Intelligent System in Rail Bhawan, New Delhi
Lighting System Upgrade in Rail Bhawan, New Delhi

description.narrative: The IRRF is UNDP’s results framework to monitor and report on its achievements against the Strategic Plan 2014-2017. UNDP publishes country level IRRF results that UNDP’s projects contributed to
Number of new development partnerships with funding for improved energy efficiency and/or sustainable energy solutions targeting underserved communities/groups and women
total number of people with improved access to energy as a result of UNDP-supported intervention

The project aims at improving energy efficiency (EE) in the Indian Railways system (and thereby reducing GHG emissions) by removing some of the key barriers that prevent the wide adoption of energy efficiency technologies and measures in the IR system.

activity-description.narrative: improving Energy efficiency in the Indian Railways System

description.narrative: 1. Develop a Status report of targeted EE technologies / measures, its availability in India/abroad and gap analysis for its implementation 2. Ensure a Functional EE Centre of Excellence (COE) 3. Number of energy audits conducted in IRS units above 0.5 MW load by year 3 4. Pilot demonstrations designed and implemented by year 5. Energy management portal functional by end of project.

comment.narrative: 1. Effectiveness of the pilot projects in the 4 zones still underway expected to be completed in 2016 2. Center of excellence website established and operational by end of 2016 3. 64 training courses conducted by the training institutes by end of 2016 4. 1000 managers and staff members trained on EE best practices and technologies by end of 2016 5. 14 successful EE projects implemented by the trained managers and staff members by end of 2016

Institutionalised energy efficiency in the Indian Railways System through creating Centres of Excellence (COE) with testing facilities/labs of equipment, and conducting trainings of more than 1000 Railway personnel. Strengthened Energy Consumption Monitoring System and developed IT based systems to monitor real time data through automated meters from 500 individual operations analysing load, monitor losses, and energy consumption trend. Demonstrated 8 energy efficient technologies/ solutions in traction and non-traction operations, cost benefit analysis done showing encouraging Return on Investments (RoIs) and making good financial case for replication. Pilot projects in 4 zones completed in 2016. 68 training courses conducted by the training institutes 4. 1156 managers and staff members trained on EE best practices and technologies. 16 successful EE projects implemented by the trained managers and staff members.
1. Building Management Intelligent system developed and implemented by end of March 2017 2. Project evaluation undertaken by end of March

Implemented Building Management Intelligent System for energy conservation and centralised control in buildings. Implemented replication plan and resource allocation for technologies/solutions demonstrated under the project. Project evaluation undertaken. Moving to the next phase 2018 onwards, initiated project development and implementation for 5 GW rooftop and land based solar deployment .

1 Institutional Barrier
a TIRFAD is set up at RDSO to collect disseminate relevant information provide technical back up to implement EE technologies

2 Information and capacity barriers
A webportal wwwrailsaverin has been developed to access information data on energy consumption for non traction traction and workshops over entire Indian Railways system An agency was hired to analyse Energy Efficiency opportunities in traction and non traction operation A report prepared by the agency is planned this year to be disseminated by Min of Railways

The energy consumption data from the web portal is being analyzed facilitating planning procurement decisions and targeted savings at zonal level and Min of Railways

An energy lab is being set up at IRIEEN It shall help in setting up the procedures for testing of electrical equipments
5 Financial Barrier
The steps implemented for the above barriers shall assist in controlling the expenditure on energy consumption and energy consuming products equipments
In addition the subprojects interventions as identified in the project shall be able to give results for energy saving of 00173 million kWh equivalent to 0117 million t CO2 per year

description.narrative: Mainstreaming coastal and marine biodiversity conservation into production sectors in the East Godavari, Andhra Pradesh.

title.narrative: A fisherman streers his boat through the back waters from the Chollengi fish landing.
Preparing ?Seascape-Landscape Level Strategic Plan for East Godavari River Estuarine Ecosystem (EGREE) Ecosystem, Andhra Pradesh?

description.narrative: Mainstreaming coastal and marine biodiversity conservation into production sectors in the East Godavari, Andhra Pradesh.

1. Establish a of cross-sectoral institutional mechanism in EGREE with representation from conservation, livelihood and production sectors. 2. Preparation of one Landscape Level Strategic Plan (SP) that provides enabling policy environment for mainstreaming biodiversity conservation into production sectors. 3. Undertake 2 Research studies on East Godavari River Estuarine Ecosystem (EGREE) 4. Number of community conservation knowledge center complex centers established 5. Number of workshops organized on landscape conservation and marine diversity 6. Number of exposure visits organised 7. Number of Knowledge products developed 8. One Management Plan revised

comment.narrative: 1. 0 2. 0 3. Limited number of research studies on EGREE available 4.0 5.0 6.0 7.0 8.0

1. A new governance model to closely work with production sectors in EGREE Region. 2. To incorporate biodiversity strategies into International, National and State Policies and guidelines like National Wildlife Action Plan, CITES, CMS, Urban Planning, A.P. State Fisheries Act and Enforcement agencies of Marine Police and Coast Guards; 3. Mainstreaming coastal and marine biodiversity conservation into other sectors by effective implementation of plans. 4. Enhance community livelihoods through eco-tourism and Small and Medium Apparel Research and Training. 5. Convert at least 3 villages with Sanitary Lavatories.

1. The EGREE Foundation, having a new governance model is closely working with production sectors in EGREE Region. 2. Successfully incorporated biodiversity strategies into International, National and State Policies and guidelines like National Wildlife Action Plan, CITES, CMS, Urban Planning, A.P. State Fisheries Act and Enforcement agencies of Marine Police and Coast Guards; 3. Mainstreaming coastal and marine biodiversity conservation into fisheries, tourism, aquaculture, oil and gas sectors by effective implementation of plans. Improved co-financing from various sectors. 4. Enhanced community livelihoods through with eco-tourism and Small and Medium Apparel Research and Training. 5. Converted 4 villages with 256 Individual Sanitary Lavatories.

1. Further strengthening of EGREE Foundation governance model in the Andhra Pradesh for strengthening coastal and marine governance. 2. Upscale findings of Evaluation of Ecosystem study and climate change impact study into various planning processes in EGREE region. 3. Mainstreaming coastal and marine biodiversity into port and shipping, fertilizers and salt pans by implementing respective sectoral policies and also implement biodiversity friendly strategic plan for whole EGREE Region through EGREE Foundation. 4. Strengthen linkages with various market business with community livelihoods and provide exit strategy.

Strengthened EGREE Foundation governance model in the Andhra Pradesh for strengthening coastal and marine governance. Upscaled findings of Evaluation of Ecosystem study findings and climate change impact study findings into various planning processes in EGREE region. Mainstreamed coastal and marine biodiversity into port and shipping, fertilizers and salt pans by implementing respective sectoral policies and also implement biodiversity friendly strategic plan for whole EGREE Region through EGREE Foundation. Strengthened linkages with various market business with community livelihoods and provide exit strategy.

description.narrative: Landscapeseascape area in the EGREE where production activities mainstream biodiversity conservation

comment.narrative: 0 ha
About 80000 ha 46450 ha as area of direct influence and 33550 ha as area of indirect influence

Within the reporting period the project activities have directly influenced about 45000 ha The detailed activities are elaborated below
A Increased level of protection of Mangroves and other habitats and enforcement in association with Coast Guard Navy and Fisheries Department B Improvement of the existing mangrove habitat by mangrove plantations of 60 acres during the reporting period C Marine Turtle National Workshop was organized for reviving turtle conservation networks in the eastern coastal states of India Training on turtle stranding for preventing turtle deaths was carried out and an Action Plan for the East Coast States of India was also discussed The outcomes of all the recommendations was compiled into a Vizag Declaration for conservation of Marine Turtles in India Preliminary proceedings cum action plan was done and detailed proceedings under preparation D Promoting Community Based EcoTourism in and around Coringa Wildlife Sanctuary and adjoining Reserve Forest areas E Coastal beach cleanup programmemes involving Coast Guard Marine Police youth local schools colleges and industries F Strengthening of enforcement departments Coast Guard Marine Police Fisheries Forest Departments etc for conserving the biodiversity of EGREE region through joint monitoring programme G Involving Corporate Sectors in Coastal and Marine Biodiversity Conservation
H Biodiversity conservation programmes were conducted for 75 Nature clubs in local schools and colleges to increase the awareness levels among the students through Wildlife Week Celebrations International Coastal Cleanup Day and Exhibitions Workshops Biodiversity Day celebrations etc I CBOs EDCs VSS SHGs further strengthened for mangrove protection and conservation and J Promotion of alternative livelihoods for reducing dependency on forests through training to youth groups on EcoTourism based NatureGuide Hospitality management and Cookery SMART programme for village girls and women on apparel training and designing center in collaboration with ATDC Hyderabad
2 Approximately 28000 ha area was indirectly influenced during the reporting period through the following
A Awareness programmes B Setting up of awareness hoardings 30 all around the EGREE Region C Increased Knowledge levels of stakeholders through publications viz booklets 1 book 1 brochures 7 posters 7 handouts 2 standees 20 D Increased awareness through Kalajatha Programmes 60 similar to street play and E 1st time in India presented the urgent need to mitigate human wildlife conflict between fishing cat and fisherman and also between otters and fishermanaquaculture farmers with appropriate statistics at National government level

1 Scyphiphora hydrophyllacea is Stable 2 Nesting habitats of the Olive Ridley Turtle both at Sacramento and Hope Island were protected between January and May The four year hatching success rate shows more or less a stabilized nestings But nesting vs hatching ratio has increased from 9141 in 2013 to 93 in 2014 and 2015 No of Nesting females have also increased from 439 in 2014 to 571 in 2015 3 Population of Fishing Cat and Indian Smooth Coated Otter are monitored through direct sighting camera traps and indirect sign surveys which indicated that the numbers is stable Intensive Grid Level Surveys are being carried out to understand behavior pattern of these animals Village level surveys being carried out to address the conservation issues and sensitize villages towards conservation of these animals and 4 The MTR suggested renaming this indicator as Red Data Index instead of species specific indicators

Based on the recommendations of the microplans the project is implementing livelihood and awareness generation activities in 37 villages in the project area Among them 10 high dependent villages have been highly prioritized and resource development alternative livelihood activities have been initiated in these villages through the Andhra Pradesh Forest and Fisheries Depts
I Fishery development of post harvest technology to the fisher men and women and supporting technically improved equipment In addition 1 Strengthening the village infrastructure a Community halls which were in bad shape were renovated as community extension and information centers and are now being used for conducting meetings awareness programmes educating the youth club women groups on biodiversity conservation etc b Constructed fish drying yard and dairy milk collection center to support the resource users for enhancing their livelihood opportunitiesc Supported construction of a hygienic market and landing space at Matlapalem with the collaboration of Fisheries department Kakinada d Fish processing centre at Chollangi Snanala Revu Highway fish stall at Kobbarichettu Peta villages e Conducted pilot fish stall with the trained women at Kakinada town to tie up with local and district retail market network for sales and marketing of the processed fish f Distributed Ecofriendly Fishing gear to 7 fishermen groups 70 fishermen at Matlapalem village
II Promoting alternative livelihoods and collaboration with institutions 2 Provided Microcredit support for establishing Micro Entrepreneurship programme to Matlapalem Uppalanka and Clollangi Snanala Revu villages based on this initiated linking this programme with AP State Government Programme Capital Infusion Fund through District Rural Development Agency DRDA EG Dt
3 Created linkages between the trained candidates of Nature Guides and Cookery courses with Andhra Pradesh Tourism Development Corporation APTDC
4 EF established Alternative Livelihood training center SMART Skill Camp in collaboration with ATDC Hyd Ministry of Jute and Textile and imparted training to 50 community women The women initiated DISHA society for textile designing and manufacturing unit Initiated tieup with DRDA industrial textile manufacturing units industries for bulk orders to the trained women
III Promoting Community based EcoTourism
5 Strengthening of Community Based Eco Tourism CBET Supported the Forest Department to construct and procure necessary infrastructure for strengthening of CBET at Chollangi and Ramannapalem Jetty Gate Arch Dust bins Murals Eco autos Publicity material etc
6 Also the Forest Department has allocated land for constructing a Centre for Community Knowledge on Coastal Conservation CCKCC under the umbrella of the EGREE Foundation

description.narrative: Decline in pesticide concentration in the effluents of aqua farms in the target landscape indicator baselines and targets will have to be revisited once the Sector Plans are prepared by midterm

comment.narrative: Baseline concentrations to be measured in 1st 3 months of project
7080 decline over baseline concentrations

The effluents released from the 10 more aquaculture farms were collected and analyzed at reputed lab at Hyderabad As all the 33 samples during 2014 were collected during winter month further to cross check the values 10 more samples were collected and analyzed No drastic seasonal variations were found All these results showed that there is a drastic decline in the pesticide concentrations in aqua farms as the State Government of Andhra Pradesh has introduced a disease resistant exotic species Litopenaeus vannamei Moreover the pesticides like Endosulphan and Nuvan have been banned by the Government from use

Not Applicable Will be rated in Final Evaluation
However the following information is provided as per the discussions held during MTR 1 The Project has initiated coordination with one of the World Bank projects called SICOM mainly for coastal zone management and will initiate integrated coastal zone management plan for EGREE region 2 The climate change studies and Evaluation of Ecosystem Studies are completed and the final report is being finalized for the EGREE region therefore this component can be evaluated during the Final Evaluation 3 The VKPCPIR corridor is under consideration and the process for it is almost finalized The negative impacts of the corridor on the ecology of the area which should be counterbalanced through various environmental mitigation measures have already been discussed in the two public hearings conducted till date In connection with the to be established LNG floating terminal and expansion of Kakinada Sea Port huge dredging activities are being under taken near Hope Island which protects Kakinada City from natural calamities Concerns and modifications required were presented and shared with concerned authorities by the GoIUNDPGEFGoAP Project team and 4 Also the combined 2nd NPSC meeting has agreed to propose the site as a Ramsar Site and the proposal has been moved in this regard

description.narrative: Landscape level Strategic Plan that provides an enabling policy environment for mainstreaming biodiversity conservation into production sectors

comment.narrative: 1 Strategic Plan

1 The Biodiversity Friendly Strategic Plan BFSP prepared and submitted to MoEFCC and the same has been forwarded to the Government of Andhra Pradesh for implementation 2 As there were several landscape level changes in the project area in the last couple of years the committee suggested revisiting the strategic plan and 3 A consultant was hired for upgrading the Biodiversity Friendly Landscape and Seascape level Plan in view of latest findings and the work has been initiated

description.narrative: Strategies developed for ensuring that existing sector policies mainstream biodiversity conservation

comment.narrative: Policies requiring amendments identified in Year 1
Strategies developed for 100 of identified policies

1 Main policies that require harmonization have been identified The Project is keenly examining amending the Wildlife Protection Act 1972 for inclusion of coastal and marine biodiversity conservation which have already been adopted in advanced countries having the similar wildlife laws 2 For the 1st time in India with the intervention of UNDPGEF Godavari Project a separate chapter on Marine Conservation has been included in the proposed Wild Life Action Plan of India from 2017 to 2031 15 years 3 Amending Andhra Pradesh Marine Fisheries Act to be in line with the aquaculture sector expansion mesh size regulations etc as recommended by the Aquaculture and Fisheries sectoral plans of GoIUNDPGEFGoAP project These were discussed with all stakeholders during the National level Consultation Workshop organized during 25th May 2015 Inputs were given on the draft Fisheries Action Plan of AP State Government and 4 Coromandel Fertilizers Kakinada operating in the EGREE Region is one of the foremost industries to incorporate the biodiversity friendly practices into their operations with the support of EGREE Foundation Coromandel Fertilizers as part of their compliance has to allot 50 of its land for plantations However the site selected for the plantation was a wetland which is a good habitat for waterbirds especially Darters In fact this habitat is recorded as home to the 2nd largest Darter population in India after Gujarat When Coromandel Fertilizers was about to start conversion of the wetland into plantation EGREE Foundation intervened and liaised with the State Pollution Control Board and assisted in obtaining permission for protecting the wetlands by requesting the local Forest Officials to provide wetland plant species which could be shown as plantations for fulfilment of forest environmental compliance With this initiative the EGREE Foundation could mainstream biodiversity conservation into production sector in around 30 acres Further EGREE Foundation was able to conserve the second largest habitat of Darters in India

Sujagriti SSYS and Sarjana were trained in the appropriate cookstove technologies at the CEESAIL project site in Gonda GSMT visited Arti to adopt cookstove designs Nagarika Trust and We Care Society adopted the cookstove technologies from TIDE
SYSS and Shashwat made visits to MGIRI to learn about new solar based technologies and adopting into the SGP projects The trainings are happening for communities and NGOs with service providers
ZIRCORD has taken up with 04 Panchayats the setting up of biomass briquettes based on ricehusk Also CCD and Sarjana are adopting low cost technologies of biobriquetting
A special meeting was organized with BAREFOOT POWER for accessing and sharing their technologies Partners like SYSS Kurseong Disha GVNML and VSK are adopting the RE technologies in their projects
SSE is exploring the opportunities for putting up microhydro unit under the project More impacts of CO2 emission reduction will emerge close to completion of the project activities

description.narrative: of women involved through SHGs in investments for emissions reductions

comment.narrative: to be assessed in the initial phase of the project
10 increase by end of year 2 and 20 increase by end of year 4

Through projects like TIDE NERD Sujagrati GVSS and Disha efforts are being made to encourage the partners to access the emission reduction technologies through investments from their savings
Presently about 5 of SHGs are making investments in adoption of such technologies through their savings Women entrepreneurs have sourced small technologies eg solar lanterns solar torches and mobile phone chargers with small penlight cells

description.narrative: Outcome 31 Improved enabling environment at the panchayat level agricultural sector improves management functionality and cover of agroecosystems in ASAR LD1
density of ground stocking in productive forest landscape in ASAR HFWG

comment.narrative: Ground stocking increased to 50

These are estimates made from the Mid Term reviews in projects and talks with locals The ground stock increase is taking place in 3 ways and Direct and Indirectly in all 3 ways
1 Plantations In 85 projects plantations are taking place due to multiple sources of financinginitiatives of SHGsForest Department and MNREGA In last 3 years more than 100000 plantations of trees with multiple species in projects
2 SWC Measures Due to introduction of soil and water conservation measures in projects the local biodiversity strengthening is already taking place As many of the works are in and around protected forest areas there is natural growth of the stock in place
3 Wood USE Savings Thirdly in several projects on improved cookstoves bio gas units have taken up in the periphery of protected areasreserved forests and this is leading to reduce pressures on forests the exact amount of saving can be gauged through each project

description.narrative: No of hectares of dry agricultural lands brought under SLM with improved vegetative cover

comment.narrative: 70000 hectares

Nearly 42000 hectares of land brought under sustainable management through 15 projects Against an allocation of US 366833 a commitment of US 264636 has been done
Majority of the projects are with the poorest of the poor and with PVTGs Particularly Vulnerable Tribal Groups in the remote areas and are in line with the national priorities eg Spandan Paramparagat CHARDEP GSS WEEDS Nishwarth and Dharti are all by the protected areas
Under GVSS project 3 large size canal bunds and under Vruksh Prem 2 checkdams were constructed and waste land brought under additional cultivation resulting in increased income of farmers by 34 times 35 hectares of degradedwaste land brought under additional cultivation in Dausa and BandiKui Districts situated on the foothills of Aravali mountain range in Rajasthan State 9 hectares of fodder land brought under additional grazing in GVNML project in Rajasthan through locally devised Chauka systems of rainwater harvesting More than 57 fodder plots developed by CONARE in Andhra Pradesh State linking with Forage Department Hyderabad Ministry of Agriculture More than 27000 mangrove plantations made in 25 hectares of land area by PPSS Machlipatnam Andhra Pradesh
Six project partners Conare SYSS GVNML Mahila Haat MNTN and Chhatrasal developed fodder plots to link up with the project activities More than 400 ha land development actions undertaken by Manuvikasa 560 ha of rice cultivation done by Sarjana 600 ha millets by Paryavaraniya Vikas 450 ha by SRIDA through demonstrations on minor millets and Jowar Sujagriti has brought 1700 ha area under cultivation through earthen bunds with spillways also called dor bandi
61 Feeding Troughs set up to divert cattle from free grazing to stall fed conditions and to reduce burden on forests Agreements done with beneficiaries that 2 of their animals will not be sent to forest for grazing
Peekay Tree Crops promoted 4 womens food processing units two tailoring units and two commercial scale protected agriculture farms 12 goat breeding rearing units one community marketing outlet one horticulture nursery and 15 quail farming units 20 family farms are supported with vegetable planting materials and 500 tree saplings
SESA PUPA PPSS MPSSS visited Fodder Institutes for accessing improved quality seeds 123 compost pits developed and linked to the slurry emanating from the biogas units set up under the project 20 at GVSS 3 at Friends of Doon Society 30 in SMS 50 in We Care Society SYSS and Mahila Haat have also developed simple pits for composting Planning started for increasing soil productivity on 1600 Ha in Muskan Jyoti
Three community institutions registered for managing the EcoPulpers by IIPM and nearly 150 water reduction has happened per day 400 litres per 1000 kgs of coffee pulping to earlier 7000 litres In the 3 centres during the last one year for 65 days of operation the reduction has been 3567000 litres of water With the successful impacts emerging the NGO is taking up a Full Scale GEF project
Nearly 23 wells constructed under the Jaldhara Schemes of the States In Gravis 4 tanks have been made of 300 cubic feet which are holding nearly 8000 litres 1 cu ft is 231 litres of water The life span of these units being 20 years the cost of water storage is 0003 paisa per litre

description.narrative: Number of new and additional sources identified for leveraging investment replication for SLM across drylands in ASAR

comment.narrative: At least 10 new sources

As explained earlier projects have leveraged resources for land development and linked to MNREGA a Government of India initiative in dry land remote districts and Watershed funds More than 45 wells recharged in the area resulting into increased irrigation NGOs like MPSS Shashwat SRIDA GVSS GSMT SAMEKIT and Gram Sathi
Many Panchayats are linking MNREGA program within the villages in projects Panchayats are providing approvals for areas for plantations road construction Mahatma Phule SRIDA Kurseong Disha Nirman Samarthak and APOWA Mangroves PPSS formation of Biodiversity Management Committees Sujagriti Sarjana KFI and SYSS All these actions will set a platform for replication activities in the projects
More partners like Dharti SYSS Niswarth and Samekit are also developing similar links in the coming year

description.narrative: Number of new grants that replicate consolidated approaches BD CC LD

comment.narrative: Replication of consolidated approaches BD CC LD in at least 30 new grants by year 4

17 replication and scaling up projects have been taken up under all the 3 GEF thematic areas and operational zed This has been undertaken with the twin objectives of broadening the areas and technologies uptake from the project and partner institutions
The projects have shown greater promise access to government Schemes GEF benefits co financing and sustainable institution creation brand building business models The focus in GEF SGP is to create a niche through scaling up and make communities responsible and have greater ownerships skills and practices Many of the projects have already developed sustainable institutions as Producer Co and Cooperatives etc for long term sustainable development

description.narrative: Number of workshopslearning events conducted by the project by the GEF SGP partnersstakeholders

comment.narrative: GEF SGP partnersstakeholders

Workshops held in the beginning of year 1 to finalise the indicators and targets in the ME framework with all the stakeholders
Four learning events organised for key stakeholdersSGP grantees for achieving this outcome

With 10 GuidancecumCapacity Building workshops organized during the last year a total of 26 workshops have been organized from the start of the OP5 project
The NGOs were guided on the linkages to be established with government programs and financial institutions and how the GEFable impacts are to be viewed in the proposals and how the cofinancing is to be accessed and the calculations done for reporting purposes
During the workshops the learnings from other projects are shared resource persons Sector Experts guide them on new available technologies and how to access them More than 15 grantees have been linked up with various RE technologies Details given in the CB section
Exchange visits as learning exercises are arranged that help the NGOs to learn from each other on how to make a Producer Company improved cultivation practices of horticulture and polyhouse culture for better yields and income A visit of Lotus Society visited was arranged to Lok Panchayat to learn about setting up of SeedGran Banks Samarthak Samiti visited Yerala Society to link up their products for marketing
Experience of GVSS on exposure visit of their farmers to Agricultural Research Institute was shared with other NGOs and how the farmers benefitted by way of increased cultivation
GVNML was encouraged to promote for the improved income the local plant variety Kair for developing value added products like pickles which are in high demand in the neighbouring cities of Rajasthan
The NGOs are briefed on how to write reports to link up with Results Based Monitoring System how to do calculation of CO2 emission reduction from their operations and how to develop quality documentation including film making
A visit was organized for 51 project partners to Central Institute of Agricultural Engineering Bhopal to learn about pre and post harvest technologies easy to operate agricultural tools and implements for reducing the time in various agricultural practices linking up with renewable energy technologies
Regular guidance is provided to the Regional Coordinators and CEE teams on how to do the handholding and guidance to the NGOsCBOs on analyzing GEF impacts institution building in projects and how to assess the measurable impacts
Support provided to Sarjana who has developed indigenous rice varieties to label them with quality ingredients and link them with markets More than 250 kgs of Rice sold through network benefitting 23 farmers

description.narrative: 1) Total Area for Solar concentrator collector area installed (m2). 2) Number of solar concentrator technology packages demonstrated 3) Number of persons trained on technical skills on solar concentrators for heat applications. 4) Number of Evaluations conducted 5) Number of newsletters and magazines published

comment.narrative: 1. Sanction 15,000 m2 of solar concentrators 2. Conduct training to 150 persons on CSH 3. Conduct online monitoring of existing CSH installations

Increased the market by four times in 2016 when compared to base year 2012 by installing/sanctioning about 60 systems cumulating to 16,000 m2. Operationalized Concentrating Solar Heat test set up at National Institute of Solar Energy, Gurgaon and University of Pune (only such facilities in Asia) – 10 systems tested. Populated project website www.cshindia.in with 42 monthly newsletter, 12 Quarterly magazine – Sun Focus, 12 Audio visuals, Compendium on 100 installations and a National toll free helpline – 1800 233 4477 has been made available.

1. Establish 15,000 m2 of solar concentrators 2. Test at least 10 CSH systems in two test centres 3. Include CSH in Bureau of Indian Standards 4. Include CSH in lending scheme of lending in Banks 5. Conduct on-line monitoring of 50 new systems

Increased Solar concentrator market 5 times compared to base year by commissioning another 70 projects (20,000 m2). Establish online monitoring for 40 systems and analyse performance. Prepared roadmap for fast tracking solar thermal to meet heat energy requirement in India (over 50% of commercial energy is spent in the form of heat). Established 20,000 m2 of Solar concentrators and tested 12 CSH systems. Included CSH in Bureau of Indian Standards and in lending scheme of four nationalized banks 5. Conducted on-line monitoring of 40 new CSH installations

description.narrative: Established Concentrating Solar Heat Technology Platform and is operational

An officially established CSH Technology Platform
Number of meetings conducted by the CSH Technology Platform by EOP
No of CSH system users that make use of the platform in addressing issuesproblems concerning energy performance and improvements of CSH systems by EOP
No of CSH system manufacturerssuppliersdistributors that make use of the platform in addressing issuesproblems concerning the market of CSH products by EOP

comment.narrative:
A CSH platform was established during the reporting period It comprises of key stakeholders from Government Technical experts Manufacturers Consultants International Organizations NGOs Test centres etc
In addition CSTEAM a manufacturers association was formed in 201314
First meeting of CSH platform was held in April 2015 with a great enthusiasm among stakeholders It is proposed to have such meeting on quarterly basis In the first meeting several issues were discussed
1 Strengthen implementation there are gaps in implementation and the CSH systems are unable to meet the claimed performance action by suppliers
2 related to financing implementation Policy Promotional activities etcThe major Issues are
3 Delay in inspection Delay in inspection by state nodal agency have multiple impacts Further there will be delay in releasing subsidies This stress on working capital of suppliers This spirals into lack of funds for further installations Action by MNRE
4 Subsidy release on case to case basis It was suggested MNRE release subsidy on casetocase basis to avoid financial stress on suppliers
5 Release the subsidy against bank guarantee MNRE informed this requires modification in the scheme further exploration
6 Issue guidelines to promote CSH systems CREDA representative suggested that the guidelines to promote CSH systems should be issued to relevant government ministries such as HRD and Health Ministry This can enable the government agencies to take up active participation and promotion of the technology in their respective establishments
In addition 2 meetings of CSTEAM by the manufacturers and 2 others of experts manufacturers in MNRE were held in 201314 making a total of 5 such meetings held so far
30 stakeholders participated in 1st CSH Platform meeting In all 80 people participated so far including of CSTEAM other stakeholder interactions organized by MNRE
Around 10 manufacturers participated in these meetings

description.narrative: Preparing Third National Communication (TNC) and other new information to the UNFCCC
Preparing Third National Communication (TNC) and other new information to the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change.

1. Update report on India's National Circumstances. 2. Prepare the Information of GHG inventory for India. 3. Increased accuracy of GHG inventory through the use of tier-III methodologies in multiple sectors. 4. Increase the accuracy of GHG inventory through the use of tier-III methodologies for most sectors. 5. Strengthened and streamlined National institutional structure for long term National GHG inventory and the estimation of GHG emissions. 6. Improve climate change projections with the use of advanced and updated Regional Climate Change models. 7. Make available and develop a clearer understanding of climate and socioeconomic scenarios for India. 8. Improve understanding of, and appropriate actions planned for addressing, vulnerability to climate change at different sectors and regions. 9. Increase understanding of Adaptation framework, measures and possible projects . 10. Increase understanding of GHG mitigation policies and measures at national and state level. 11. Increase understanding of gaps and constraints pertaining to financial, technical and capacity needs to address climate change. 12. Develop a Comprehensive description of systematic observations and research on climate change. 13. Enhance understanding of domestic mitigation actions, its need and the level/nature of support required, greenhouse gas emissions inventory and other related information.

comment.narrative: Mechanisms in place for the implementation of the HCFC phase-out activities
• Provide technical assistance to implement the non HCFC based technologies in the 15 foam manufacturing and 15 System Houses

• MOAs got amended to extend their validity • UNDP appointed a consultant to conduct the re- verification and the verification of the remaining enterprises on the request of the Govt. • UNDP provided technical assistance and disbursed amount towards the completion of activities as per the milestones under MoA on the recommendations of Govt.

• Provide technical assistance to implement the non HCFC based technologies in the 15 foam manufacturing and 15 System Houses • Monitor the gaps and challenges hindering the implementation of the activities as per MoA by the foam manufacturing enterprises and System Houses

• Consultations and meetings conducted with the enterprises to understand the challenges faced in the implementation of the non HCFC based technologies • Regular follow ups were made to accelerate the implementation of the pending activities as per the MoA • The verification of milestones got completed by the third party consultant and final reports issued • All the All 15 foam manufacturing companies successfully completed the technology conversion to cyclopentane from HCFC based blowing agent. • 10 SHs completed the conversion to support the formulation of non HCFC based blowing agent • The disbursement of the fund to the enterprises that have completed the activities as per MoA are under process.

comment.narrative: (1) Draft guidelines on community forest resource management has been prepared which is under consideration of the Ministry of Tribal Affairs and Ministry of Environment, Forest and Climate Change (2) Draft of the national Tribal Human Development Report has been shared with the Ministry of Tribal Affairs for approval for release (3) National Web-based Monitoring Portal designed and operationalized for reporting by districts and states on Forest Rights Act implementation. (4) Technical support and cross learning contributed in recognition of more than 100,000 rights for habitation, self- cultivation and over community forest resources to the forest dwelling communities under the Forest Rights Act 2006 (5) Web-based MIS Application to monitor the allocation, utilization and reach out of intended benefits to the Scheduled Tribes developed; (6) National Resource Centre on Tribal Livelihood established to promote skill development and entrepreneurship promotion in tribal areas

comment.narrative: 1. No strategy available for difficult districts 2. 0 3. 0 4. 0 5. 0

1. State specific strategies for focus districts rolled out in Chhattisgarh, Jharkhand, and Odisha, with emphasis on inclusion in social, political and economic spheres 2. Inclusion and efficiency strengthened in rural livelihoods 3. Increased effectiveness in skill development programmes for rural areas 4. Implementation of MGNREGA strengthened through development and operationalisation of tools and resources 5. Appropriate and affordable housing options for the rural poor developed and demonstrated 6. Tools, mechanisms and models developed for addressing rural deprivations

1. The Action plans for all the 3 states approved by PSC and implementation started. • 72 Producer Groups set up covering 35,897 families in Odisha and Chhattisgarh. • Convergence initiated in 12 districts leading to 33% increase in HHs under NRLM; 9,199 trained, 3,278 placed under DDU-GKY & Roshni projects; 1,453 trained under RSETI; 5,738 SHGs linked to banks; 41,361 HHs covered under AABY; PRI-CBO convergence rolled out in 8 Gram Panchayats.
2. Embedded UNDP experts contributed to: • Development of a competitive funding mechanism to support livelihoods projects at sub state level. 15 states have received assistance of $12M to benefit about 90,000 households. • Preparation and roll out of Vulnerable Reduction Fund (VRF) for greater inclusion of extreme poor and vulnerable. 16 states have received about $2.5M for 3,024 Village Organisations to reach 200,000 households • 4.7M households have been mobilized into self-help groups, with more than 50% from Dalit/Tribal/Minority groups. • Women Farmer’s programme scaled up to 17 states covering 3.4M farmers.
3. UNDP professionals contributed to • Training of 2,08,176 youth in employable skills. • Rolling out of the Public Financial Management System (PFMS) to 18 states. • Development of on-line project appraisal tool and sharing with with states for effective-efficient risk-based monitoring. • UNDP completed a market study for potential in overseas employment.
4. UNDP technical support led to • Facilitation of 2,956M person days of labour - leading to creation of 1M durable assets for deprived households including 0.54M household toilets, 0.35M ponds, 67,000 vermi/NADEP compost pits and 3,329 health-nutrition centres. • Skilling of 42,517 individuals from casual labour households as barefoot engineers, masons, etc. • Training of 270,000 persons for geo-tagging durable assets created. • Linking unique identity numbers for 35.6M MGNREGA workers with their bank ac

1. Scalable intervention model created through focus districts approach with strong emphasis on convergence, social & financial inclusion and livelihoods promotion 2. Inclusion and efficiency strengthened in rural livelihoods 3. Increased efficiency & Enhanced Quality in Programme implementation and Monitoring of DDU-GKY 4. Implementation of MGNREGA strengthened through effective planning, development and operationalisation of tools and resources 5. Appropriate and affordable housing options for the rural poor developed and demonstrated 6. Tools, mechanisms and models developed for addressing rural deprivations

100,000 vulnerable households in 12 LWE districts accessed major entitlements-benefits through successful piloting of 3-tier GIS-Enabled Entitlement Tracking (GEET) System. 100,000 vulnerable households in 12 LWE districts benefitted from focused livelihoods interventions. 1,000 demonstration houses set up and a cadre of 50,000 masons trained using appropriate technology. NRM-based planning and asset creations through convergence between MGNREGA, NRLM, PMKSY, IWMP and MoWR benefitted 112 irrigation-deprived districts, 1,068 over-exploited blocks, 217 critical blocks and 2 Million households; Rural manual casual labourer households are provided with Job Cards under MGNREGA (Willing households among 5.37 Cr).

1. Legal Literacy content mainstreamed and disseminated through Sakshar Bharat in 62 districts of Uttar Pradesh and 32 districts of Rajasthan. 2. 686 panchayats of Barabanki districts, UP and 55 panchayats of Sehore district of MP provided with legal literacy materials. 3. Legal literacy mainstreamed in 500 Common Service Centres across seven districts of Rajasthan reaching out to a target population of 50,000 persons. 4. 20,000 persons provided with justice services through justice hubs in three districts of Jharkhand.

1.5 million marginalized people reached out for awareness on the rights and entitlements and legal aid through law school based legal aid clinics, national adult literacy programme and common service centers. Innovative legal awareness interventions scaled up in coordination with other Government Departments/ Programmes e.g. CSCs (DeITY), NLMA, SIRDs. Technical Team in National Mission on Justice Delivery and Legal Reforms provided inputs on key judicial reforms. e.g. scope of Judicial Accountability Bill, criminal justice system, strengthening alternate dispute resolution mechanisms/pre-litigation mediation. In UP, SIRD developed IEC materials and training of 500 Village Level Resource Persons and campaign on legal literacy in target 779 Gram panchayats and developed an online monitoring application to track campaign. NLMA’s Sakshar Bharat organised trainings of 200 Resource Persons (RPs) and 600 preraks to mainstream legal literacy across 62 districts of UP. Common Service Centre (CSC) e-Governance India Limited trained of 50 VLEs in 3 districts of Jharkhand and 500 VLEs across 500 CSCs - 11 districts of Rajasthan reaching out to 28,000 people (49% women). 10 CSCs across the three districts in Jharkhand converted into digital Justice hubs – reaching out to 89,465 including 43432 men and 46033 women. In Jharkhand 52 community radio programs were developed for raising legal awareness among communities.

1. Technical Assistance to provide research/inputs to the National Mission on issues relating to legislations to ensure reduction in pendency, re-engineering procedures and alternative disputes resolution, ease of doing business (enforcement of contracts). 2. Increased awareness of 1060 Village level Resource Persons from 8 block of UP and conduct an end line survey for impact assessment 3. Provide training to 200 Preraks of NLMA from 40 districts in UP on social welfare legislations 4. Develop scale up plans in convergence with other Government schemes/programmes/departments for mainstreaming legal awareness/legal aid

Strengthened Alternate Dispute Resolution mechanism, and created awareness for the tool as effective means of disputes for marginalized through TA to National Mission. Mainstreamed legal literacy through synergy between various stakeholders towards achieving the Vision 2020 – Access to Justice for All. Enrich the quality of legal aid through a dynamic clinical legal education programme.

description.narrative: 1. Capacities developed to support gender sensitive climate change planning and implementation at the sub-national level. 2. Capacities strengthened of government officers and institutions on climate change issues through the establishment of a Center for Climate Change and Environment within the NIAR/ LBSNAA

comment.narrative: India is actively engaged in addressing climate change through its domestic actions as well as engagement at the international negotiations and discussions. The National Action Plan on Climate Change launched in 2008 is a part of the concerted domestic actions to address climate change. The NAPCC comprises eight sectoral missions with multi-pronged, long-term and integrated strategies for addressing climate change. Importantly, the NAPCC clearly highlights the differentiated impacts of climate change on women - “The impacts of climate change could prove particularly severe for women. With climate change, there would be an increasing scarcity of water, reduction of yields in forest biomass, and increased risks to human health for children, women and the elderly in a household becoming the most vulnerable. With the possibility of decline in the availability of food grains, the threat of malnutrition may also increase. All these would add to deprivations that many women already encounter and so in each of the adaptation programmes, special attention should be paid to the aspect of gender.”

1. Climate Change Cells and inter-departmental working groups to be formed and operational. 2. Capacity building programmes for state nodal agency to be develop and implemented 3. Monitoring and Evaluation System to track the imlementation of SAPCC to be developed and in use 4. Sources of External funds to be identified and approached 5. Number of key officials from identified sectoral departments to be trained on climate change issues 6. Budgets for climate change actions to be allocated 7. Number of Exposure visits to be conducted

1. Inter-departmental working groups constituted and operational in all the three states - To achieve sustainability of the project outcome, systems and procedures was created which was institutionalized at the nodal agency and at department level so that climate change actions are mainstreamed into the planning processes of the states. Inter-departmental working group comprising of nodal officers from sectoral departments and nodal agencies was constituted to implement the SAPCC. State PMUs are integrated with the state Nodal agencies to ensure close interactions on a daily basis for smooth implementation of project activities. 2. Assessment of technical and functional capacities of the State Nodal Agency and sectoral departments for Water Resources, Forests, Energy and Disaster Management for planning, implementation and monitoring of the SAPCC undertaken. Based on the findings from the assessment, a realistic and time-bound capacity development plan has been proposed for the states. 3. ToR for Monitoring and Evaluation frameworks for monitoring the progress on implementation of the SAPCC in the focus sectors developed in consultation with the States. The same will be designed and developed by the Helvetas Swiss Intercooperation. 4. • Four proposals and related documents prepared on climate change actions in consultation with the State departments which are as follows: o Detailed Project Report (DPR) on “Addressing Climate Change vulnerability of water Sector at Gram Panchayat Level in drought prone areas of Sikkim” – INR 2470 lakhs was approved under National Adaptation Fund on Climate Change (NAFCC). o Improved Rainwater Harvesting Methods to increase Ground Water Recharge and Irrigation in Water Stressed 18 Villages in Kot Block, Dist. Pauri Garhwal of Uttarakhand – submitted under NAFCC. o Enhancing Adaptive Capacity to Climate Change through Conservation of Traditional Water Supply Sources (Wells and Bawadies) of Burhanpur City – submitted under CCAP.

Vulnerability and Risk mapping of the water, forest, disaster and energy sector in the three states to be prepared 4. Identification, Shortlisting and prioritization of the climate actions to be done 5. Project proposals for implementation to be developed 6. Expertise for implementation to be made available 7. Quantum of funds leveraged from additional resources to be done 8. Number of Exposure visits to be conducted 9. Training Materials to be developed 10. Project website to be developed

Approx. 450 rural community members trained in disaster preparedness and climate resilience across Sikkim.  Awareness program completed on spring-shed management in 12 drought-prone blocks in Sikkim. Approximately 400 rural community members sensitised across Sikkim  A training session was organized for the sectoral department of Govt. of Uttarakhand for strengthening the capacities of state level departments and relevant institutions to undertake specific interventions in the relevant sectors taking in to account the current and future impact of Climate Change; and discuss mainstreaming adaptive measures in to the ongoing scheme under development plan and to make the sector climate resilient 2.
